title: South Korea minister says GM Korea needs to be able to survive on own in long-term
text:
April 16, 2018 / 4:17 AM / Updated an hour ago South Korea minister says GM Korea needs to be able to survive on own in long-term Reuters Staff 1 Min Read 
SEOUL (Reuters) - South Korea’s finance minister said on Monday that public funds could only be used to support the South Korean auto unit of General Motors Co ( GM.N ) if it was clear that the business could survive on its own long-term. Vehicles are assembled at an assembly line of GM Korea's Bupyeong plant in Incheon, South Korea March 29, 2018. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji 
Speaking to reporters after a policy meeting in Seoul, Kim Dong-yeon said major shareholders and other parties involved need to swiftly come to an agreement on sharing the burden of improving the loss-making operation. 
GM shocked South Korea in February with plans to close one local plant and leaving the fate of three others unclear. It is seeking government funding and incentives as well as wage concessions to save the unit, which just posted an annual net loss of $1.1 billion (£771.4 million), its fourth straight year in the red. Reporting by Shin-hyung Lee and Cynthia Kim; Editing by Edwina Gibbs
